title: An Optimal Control Problem Arising in Sailboat Trajectory Optimization

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We formulate the optimal control problem for a sailboat aiming to reach an upwind buoy, assuming that the wind speed is constant and the wind direction follows a Brownian motion. The yacht navigates in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ and the target is a ball of radius $\eta>0$ centered at the origin. We derive the equations of motion and provide their closed-form solution. The yacht is subject to a tacking cost $c \geq 0$. We define two control problems, one where $c=0$ and another where $c>0$. For both cases, we establish an analytical upper bound on the value function by constructing a strategy that enables the yacht to reach the buoy within a finite expected number of tacks. For the case with $c=0$, where no tacking cost applies, we conjecture an optimal strategy which may involve an infinite number of tacks. The controlled state equation has non-continuous coefficients so standard results on existence and uniqueness of a strong solution do not apply. We provide a proof using the Yamada-Watanabe argument.


Mathematics Subject Classification 2020: Primary 49N90, 93E20, 60H10; Secondary 37A50, 93B52
Keywords: Stochastic control; sailboat trajectory optimization; route planning.

## 1 Introduction

In this paper we formalize, under a stochastic control perspective, the problem of a sailboat trying to minimize the time to reach an upwind buoy. The motion of the sailboat is influenced by the wind, and on certain time scales, the fluctuations of the wind direction and wind speed can be considered as random. The optimization of the sailboat's trajectory can then be viewed as a stochastic control problem.

In the past years, there has been some scientific literature specific to yacht routing problem. This consists mostly of numerical studies such as the ones in [2, 4]. In these works, the authors use statistical analysis of wind fluctuations, before discretizing the race field, the possible wind directions and the boat's motion in order to solve the the problem of finding the fastest route by stochastic optimization methods. In [5], the authors numerically solve a Markov decision process. There are several works of A. B. Philpott and coauthors, including [10, 12, 13, 11]. In particular [12] presents two models for optimizing yacht routes. The first one is intended for short distance races and the wind is modeled with a Markov chain. The second one treats ocean races and the wind is modeled using long time weather forecasts. Similarly as in [4], they

numerically compute tacking strategies which minimize the expected travel time. More recently, see for example [8] and [17], the problem is formulated with an hybrid control approach and solved numerically with semi-Lagrangian iterative schemes. Another part of works on sailing races that can be found in literature considers the question of winning a race over an opponent, instead of trying to race as fast as possible. This brings into play game theory as in [14, 15]. A simpler, one-dimensional model, is found in [3], where the authors provide a closed form solution.

This is the first work which establishes, to the best of our knowledge, a fully probabilistic approach to the sailboat trajectory optimization problem, without recurring to numerical methods. We propose models of an upwind regatta which capture some of the features of the original problem, but which remains amenable to explicit rigorous solutions that can be proved to be optimal. The results that are presented are extracted from $[1,16]$.

For a sailboat traveling upwind, one of the most critical choices is deciding when to tack, that is, to change course in such a way that, if the wind was coming from one side of the boat before the tack, it will come from the opposite side afterward. Since this maneuver slows down the yacht, it is natural to model the time lost during a tacking by a "tacking penalty" denoted by $c$ in the sequel. We consider a circular target-buoy that has positive radius $\eta>0$ and tacking penalty that may be strictly positive or null. In our model, the wind direction fluctuates as a Brownian motion with a fixed volatility $\sigma$. The wind speed is assumed constant during the whole race, so is the boat speed, denoted by $v$.

We begin by doing a coordinates change and aligning the reference frame to the wind direction. This approach enables to define the equations of motion more intuitively and derive a closed-form solution, see Proposition 2.1 and Proposition 2.2. Then, we define the control problems both for the case $c=0$ and $c>0$. In the first one, a change of direction of the yacht does not slow it down. The set of admissible strategies consists of jointly measurable and adapted processes, see Definition 3.1. Hence, there is a possibility of an infinite number of tacks on any compact set, since they are done at no cost. The second problem introduces a fixed cost for tacking. This changes drastically the sailing strategy and places the mathematical formulation of the problem in the context of optimal stochastic control problems with switching costs. In this last case, admissible strategies are piecewise constant processes, see Definition 3.4.

For $c>0$, we construct a sailing strategy that allows the yacht to reach the target buoy within a time and a number of tacks whose expectation is bounded. We provide an analytical expression for the bound which depends on the speed of the boat and the volatility of the wind, see Theorem 4.14 .

In case of no tacking cost, we improve the result of Theorem 4.14 by conjecturing the optimal strategy $A^{*}$. Under this strategy, the yacht will reach the target buoy within $\sqrt{2} \frac{c_{0}-\eta}{c}$ units of time. This bound, therefore, does not depend on the volatility of the wind. The proof that the state equation driven by $A^{*}$ admits a unique strong solution does not follow by standard results, because of the lack of continuity of the coefficients, so we provide a new one using the Yamada-Watanabe argument. Optimality of the conjectured optimal strategy will be proved in a companion paper.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we explain some terminology, perform the change of coordinates and provide the closed form solution to equations of motion. Section 3 formulates the control problems for the two cases $c=0$ and $c>0$. In Section 4, we derive the bound on the Value function. Finally, Section 5 deals with the conjectured optimal strategy $A^{*}$ for the case $c=0$.

Figure 1: No go zone.

# 2 Model 

In this section, we first explain some basic terminology of sailing that will be used throughout the paper. We then present our model and derive the equations of the position process in both polar and Cartesian coordinates.

### 2.1 Terminology

If the angle between the boat's heading and the direction of the wind (see Fig. 1) is too narrow, then the boat cannot move forward in this direction. The set of all the angles for which the boat cannot advance is called the no go zone. When the wind enters the sails from the right (resp. left) side of the yacht, the yacht is sailing on starboard tack (resp. port tack). A boat sailing upwind can switch from starboard to port tack, or vice versa, by tacking. During a tacking, the yacht enters the no-go zone and hence for a few seconds, it is no longer propelled by the wind. The yacht slows down and it is its inertia that allows it to turn to the other tack. Similarly, if the boat is sailing downwind, then the switch from one tack to the other is called a jibe.

For a given wind speed, the velocity of the yacht is a function of the angle between the wind direction and the yacht's heading. This function is illustrated by polar diagrams, see Fig. 2.

When we want to get closer to a particular point, say a buoy, then unless this point lies in the no-go zone with respect to the yacht, we can simply head directly towards it and this determines the tack on which to sail.

However, if the position of the buoy with respect to the yacht is in the no go zone, then the yacht has to follow a zigzag trajectory (see Fig. 3). This is called beating upwind: the yacht alternates between routes on starboard and on port tack while trying to sail with the optimal upwind angle, which is the angle in the polar diagram that maximizes the projection of the velocity vector onto the vertical axis (In Fig. 2, this is $\alpha_{0}=45^{\circ}$ ). Likewise, it is not optimal to aim directly at a buoy which lies leeward. The yacht will reach it more quickly by following zigzags of a given angle.

In our model (see Fig. 2), we consider that the yacht's behavior is symmetric if it is beating upwind or running downwind. The optimal angle for an upwind route is fixed at $45^{\circ}$, while for a downwind route, it is $135^{\circ}$. Between these angles, the yacht sails at constant speed $v>0$ and thus, the polar is a quarter of circle instead of the usual heart shaped curve, see Fig. 2.

When the yacht is beating upwind or running downwind, it must sail at angle $\alpha_{0}$ on one

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2: Example of a polar diagram with an 20 knots wind speed (on the left-hand side) and our modeling (on the right-hand side) where the optimal angle for an upwind route is fixed at $45^{\circ}$ and for a downwind route, at $135^{\circ}$.
tack, then tack (resp. jibe), continue at angle $\alpha_{0}$ on the other tack and repeat this again until the target is reached (see Fig. 3). Many possible tacking strategies can be employed, and in a constant wind, this does not affect the total distance traveled. However, each tack (resp. jibe) impacts the time required. In the present work the exact definition of a strategy and of a best "on average" strategy is going to be given.

In general, both the wind speed and the wind direction change over time. It turns out that moderate fluctuations of wind speed are less relevant than those of wind direction, so we assume that the wind speed is constant. For the wind direction, following [2], we assume that it follows a Brownian motion.

In order to describe the boat's position, for mathematical simplicity, we have chosen to attach the reference frame to the wind instead of to geographic directions. In order to have an understanding of the problem in this new reference frame, assume first that the wind direction is constant and parallel to the vector $(1,1) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$. The motion on starboard (resp. port) tack is shown on the right (resp. left) hand side of Fig. 4, where the yacht is forced to tack (or jibe) on the half line $d^{1}$ (resp $d^{-1}$ ) shown in the figure (since we will be interested in approaching the origin rather than moving away from it). The grey shaded areas represent the feasible headings of the boat. For each position of the boat and each tack, we choose the direction which points closest to the target. Therefore for each position of the boat, we will only allow two headings, represented by the arrows in Fig. 4, one corresponding to port tack and the other corresponding to starboard tack.

In a fluctuating wind, but with the reference frame attached to the wind, the wind is still represented by a constant vector that is parallel to the vector $(1,1) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, and it is the boat which is subject both to the displacement induced by sailing and to a Brownian rotation.In this description, a clockwise change of wind direction corresponds to a counterclockwise rotation of the boat's position, and vice-versa.

Figure 3: On the left hand side is an example of a tacking strategy for a boat beating upwind under a constant wind. A boat starting at the same point and following any other zigzag parallel to the laylines, would travel the same distance up to the target (dotted trajectory). On the right hand side is an example of a possible trajectory of the boat when the wind direction changes over time as indicated by the arrows at the top of the figure. The right-hand wings (resp. left-hand wings) of the butterfly shaped regions correspond to the feasible directions which can be achieved by sailing on port tack (resp. starboard tack).
