# 2.2 Position Process 

The purpose of this section is to write the position of the yacht as a 2-dimensional Itô process. Let $\eta>0$ and define the circular target buoy centered at the origin:

$$
\mathbb{B}_{\eta}:=\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \leq \eta\right\}
$$

In order to describe the motion in our model, we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
d^{1} & =\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: x=-y \text { and } x>0\right\} \\
d^{-1} & =\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: x=-y \text { and } x<0\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

and we split $\mathbb{R}_{*}^{2}=\mathbb{R}^{2} \backslash\{(0,0)\}$ into several zones (see Fig.5):

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & =\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: x \geq 0 \text { and } y \geq 0\right\} \cap \mathbb{R}_{\eta}^{c}, \quad I I=\left(I I^{a} \cup I I^{b} \cup d^{-1}\right) \cap \mathbb{R}_{\eta}^{c} \\
I I I & =\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: x \leq 0 \text { and } y \leq 0\right\} \cap \mathbb{B}_{\eta}^{c}, \quad I V=\left(I V^{a} \cup I V^{b} \cup d^{1}\right) \cap \mathbb{B}_{\eta}^{c}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
I I^{a}=\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: x<0 \text { and } y>-x\right\}, & I I^{b}=\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: y>0 \text { and } y<-x\right\} \\
I V^{a}=\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: y<0 \text { and } y>-x\right\}, & I V^{b}=\left\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}: x>0 \text { and } y<-x\right\}
\end{array}
$$

Let $\sigma>0$ be a given number and $\left(B_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ be a standard real-valued Brownian motion defined on a filtered probability space $\left(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}\right\}_{t \geq 0}, \mathbb{P}\right)$. In our model, $B_{t}$ represents the wind direction at time $t$.

Recall (see e.g. [9, p.65]) that if $\vec{\mu}_{c}$ and $\vec{\Sigma}$ are two functions from $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ defined by

$$
\vec{\mu}_{c}(\vec{x})=-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} \vec{x} \quad \text { and } \quad \vec{\Sigma}(\vec{x})=\vec{\Sigma}(x, y)=(-\sigma y, \sigma x)
$$

then the unique solution $\vec{X}$ of the system of stochastic differential equations

$$
d \vec{X}_{t}=\vec{\mu}_{c}\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right) d t+\vec{\Sigma}\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right) d B_{t}, \quad \vec{X}_{0}=\vec{x}=(x, y)
$$

is a Brownian motion on the circle with speed $\sigma$, given by

$$
\vec{X}_{t}=\left(\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) x-\sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) y, \sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) x+\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) y\right)
$$

In the frame attached to the wind, the process $\vec{X}$ defines the position of a motionless yacht.
We now define the functions that correspond to each possible sailing direction of a moving yacht. For $\vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, set

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\vec{\mu}_{u}(\vec{x})=(0, v), & \text { (up) } & \vec{\mu}_{d}(\vec{x})=(0,-v), \quad \text { (down) } \\
\vec{\mu}_{\ell}(\vec{x})=(-v, 0), & \text { (left) } & \vec{\mu}_{e}(\vec{x})=(v, 0), \quad \text { (right) } \\
\vec{\mu}_{\rho}(\vec{x})=-v \frac{\vec{x}}{\|\vec{x}\|}, & \text { (radial) } &
\end{array}
$$

The function corresponding to the starboard tack (resp. port tack) is denoted as $\vec{\mu}(\vec{x}, 1)$ (resp $\vec{\mu}(\vec{x},-1)$ ). According to Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\vec{\mu}(\vec{x}, 1)=\vec{\mu}_{d}(\vec{x}) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{k_{c} l V^{n}\right\}}(\vec{x})+\vec{\mu}_{r}(\vec{x}) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{I l k_{c} l V^{n}\right\}}(\vec{x})+\vec{\mu}_{\rho}(\vec{x}) \mathbf{1}_{\{I I\}}(\vec{x})+\vec{\mu}_{c}(\vec{x}) \\
\vec{\mu}(\vec{x},-1)=\vec{\mu}_{\ell}(\vec{x}) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{k_{c} I I^{n}\right\}}(\vec{x})+\vec{\mu}_{u}(\vec{x}) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{I l k_{c} I I^{n}\right\}}(\vec{x})+\vec{\mu}_{\rho}(\vec{x}) \mathbf{1}_{\{I V\}}(\vec{x})+\vec{\mu}_{c}(\vec{x})
\end{gathered}
$$

The position process of a yacht sailing on starboard tack, respectively on port tack, is now the solution of the following system of SDEs:

$$
d \vec{X}_{t}=\vec{\mu}\left(\vec{X}_{t}, 1\right) d t+\vec{\Sigma}\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right) d B_{t}, \quad \vec{X}_{0}=\vec{x}_{0}
$$

respectively,

$$
d \vec{X}_{t}=\vec{\mu}\left(\vec{X}_{t},-1\right) d t+\vec{\Sigma}\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right) d B_{t}, \quad \vec{X}_{0}=\vec{x}_{0}
$$

The next two propositions lead to the solution of these SDEs.
Proposition 2.1. Let $\vec{x}=(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ and $v_{1}, v_{2} \in \mathbb{R}$. The process $\left(\vec{X}_{t}=\left(X_{t}, Y_{t}\right)\right), t \in] 0,+\infty[$, taking values in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ and defined by

$$
\vec{X}_{t}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) x-\sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) y-v_{1} \int_{0}^{t} \cos \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s+v_{2} \int_{0}^{t} \sin \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s \\
\sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) x+\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) y-v_{1} \int_{0}^{t} \sin \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s-v_{2} \int_{0}^{t} \cos \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s
\end{array}\right)
$$

is the unique solution of

$$
\begin{cases}d X_{t}=\left(-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} X_{t}-v_{1}\right) d t-\sigma Y_{t} d B_{t}, & X_{0}=x \\ d Y_{t}=\left(-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} Y_{t}-v_{2}\right) d t+\sigma X_{t} d B_{t}, & Y_{0}=y\end{cases}
$$

Proof. Uniqueness follows directly from [9, Thm. 5.2.1], since the drift, as well as the diffusion coefficient in (2.6), are affine. Thus, it only remains to verify that the process $\vec{X}$ defined by (2.5) is indeed a solution of (2.6) using Itô's formula. For details see [16, Prop. 5.1].

Proposition 2.2. Let $\vec{x}=(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}_{*}^{2}$. The process $\left(\vec{X}_{t}, t \in\left[0, \frac{\|\vec{x}\|}{c}-\eta\right]\right)$ taking values in $\mathbb{R}^{2} \cap \mathbb{B}_{q}^{c}$ defined by

$$
\vec{X}_{t}=\binom{X_{t}}{Y_{t}}=\binom{(\|\vec{x}\|-v t) \cos \left(\sigma B_{t}+\theta\right)}{(\|\vec{x}\|-v t) \sin \left(\sigma B_{t}+\theta\right)}
$$

where $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$ is such that $\cos (\theta)=\frac{\pi}{\|\vec{x}\|}$ and $\sin (\theta)=\frac{\theta}{\|\vec{x}\|}$, is the unique solution of

$$
\begin{cases}d X_{t}=\left(-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} X_{t}-\frac{v X_{t}}{\left\|\vec{X}_{t}\right\|}\right) d t-\sigma Y_{t} d B_{t}, & X_{0}=x \\ d Y_{t}=\left(-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} Y_{t}-\frac{v Y_{t}}{\left\|\vec{X}_{t}\right\|}\right) d t+\sigma X_{t} d B_{t}, & Y_{0}=y\end{cases}
$$

Proof. Observe that the drift coefficient in (2.8) is Lipschitz continuous in $\mathbb{R}^{2} \cap \mathbb{B}_{q}^{c}$, hence the existence and uniqueness of the solution holds on $t \in\left[0, \frac{\|\vec{x}\|}{v}-n\right]$. It remains to verify that the process $\vec{X}$ defined by (2.7) is indeed a solution of (2.8). For details see [16, Prop. 5.2].

We see that the system (2.8) can also be written

$$
d \vec{X}_{t}=\left(\vec{\mu}_{c}\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right)+\vec{\mu}_{\rho}\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right)\right) d t+\sigma\left(\vec{X}_{t}\right) d B_{t}, \quad \vec{X}_{0}=\vec{x}, \quad t \in\left[0, \frac{\|\vec{x}\|}{v}\right]
$$

which corresponds to the equation satisfied by the position process of a yacht sailing radially in direction of the buoy. This happens if the boat is sailing on port tack in zone $I V$ or on starboard tack in zone $I I$.

On the other hand, Proposition 2.1 gives us the system of SDEs and the corresponding solutions for the other four motions:
(1) downward motion $\left(v_{1}=0, v_{2}=v\right)$ when the boat is on starboard tack in zone $I \cup I V^{a}$,
(2) upward motion $\left(v_{1}=0, v_{2}=-v\right)$ when the boat is on port tack in zone $I I^{b} \cup I I I$,
(3) leftward motion $\left(v_{1}=v, v_{2}=0\right)$ when the boat is on port tack in zone $I \cup I I^{a}$,
(4) rightward motion $\left(v_{1}=-v, v_{2}=0\right)$ when the boat is on starboard tack in zone $I I I \cup I V^{b}$.

Therefore, Prop. 2.1 and Prop. 2.2 provide explicit formulas to describe the solution of (2.3) and (2.4).
Remark 2.3. Denote $\left(X_{t}^{1}, Y_{t}^{1}\right)$ (resp. $\left.\left(X_{t}^{-1}, Y_{t}^{-1}\right)\right)$ the process defined by (2.3) (resp. (2.4)). Define $\tau_{f}^{a}:=\inf \left\{t:\left(X_{t}^{a}, Y_{t}^{a}\right) \in d^{a} \cup \mathbb{B}_{q}\right\}, a \in\{-1,+1\}$ where $d^{1}$, and $d^{-1}$ are defined in (2.1). Equation (2.3) (resp. (2.4)) have Lipschitz continuous coefficients in $\mathbb{R}^{2} \backslash d^{1}$ (resp. $\mathbb{R}^{2} \backslash d^{-1}$ ), therefore by a standard localization argument, there exists a strong solution until time $\tau_{f}^{1}$ (resp. $\left.\tau_{f}^{-1}\right)$, for any initial condition $\bar{x}_{0}=\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2} \backslash d^{1}\left(\operatorname{resp} \bar{x}_{0}=\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2} \backslash d^{-1}\right)$.

For later use, the equations of motion are also written in radial coordinates. For definiteness, we consider angles in $\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$ and the general case is then obtained by periodic extension. Let us consider, for instance, the process describing a yacht sailing downwind. Setting $v_{1}=0$ and $v_{2}=v$ in (2.5), we see that the position process $\vec{X}$ satisfies

$$
\begin{cases}d X_{t}=-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} X_{t} d t-\sigma Y_{t} d B_{t}, & X_{0}=x \\ d Y_{t}=\left(-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2} Y_{t}-v\right) d t+\sigma X_{t} d B_{t}, & Y_{0}=y\end{cases}
$$

Applying Itô's formula to $R_{t}=\sqrt{\left(X_{t}\right)^{2}+\left(Y_{t}\right)^{2}}$ and $\Theta_{t}=\arctan \left(Y_{t} / X_{t}\right)$, we get, after simplification,

$$
R_{t}=R_{0}-\int_{0}^{t} v \frac{Y_{s}}{R_{s}} d s=R_{0}-\int_{0}^{t} v \sin \left(\Theta_{s}\right) d s
$$

and

$$
\Theta_{t}=\Theta_{0}-\int_{0}^{t} \frac{v \cos \left(\Theta_{s}\right)}{R_{s}} d s+\int_{0}^{t} \sigma d B_{s}
$$

In other words, the process $\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t}\right)$ satisfies

$$
\begin{cases}d R_{t}=-v \sin \left(\Theta_{t}\right) d t, & R_{0}=\|\vec{x}\| \\ d \Theta_{t}=-\frac{v \cos \left(\Theta_{t}\right)}{R_{t}} d t+\sigma d B_{t}, & \Theta_{0}=\arctan (y / x)\end{cases}
$$

We do the same for all other sailing directions and we find that the position of the yacht in polar coordinates $\left(R_{t}^{a}, \Theta_{t}^{a}\right)_{t \geq 0}$, for $a \in\{-1,1\}$, is the solution of

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}^{a}=\mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}^{a}, a\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{a}=\mu_{2}\left(R_{t}^{a}, \Theta_{t}^{a}, a\right) d t+\sigma d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

on $\left\{t<\tau_{f}^{a}\right\}$, where $\tau_{f}^{a}$ is defined in Remark 2.3, and $\vec{\mu}(r, \theta, a)=\left(\mu_{1}(\theta, a), \mu_{2}(r, \theta, a)\right)$ is given, for $\theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$, by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{\mu}(r, \theta, 1)=\vec{\mu}_{d}(r, \theta) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{2}\left[\right]\right\}+\vec{\mu}_{\rho}(r, \theta) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\theta \in\left[\frac{3 \pi}{4}, \pi\left[\right]\right\}+\vec{\mu}_{r}(r, \theta) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\theta \in\left[\pi, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right]\right\}}\right.}\right. \\
& \vec{\mu}(r, \theta,-1)=\vec{\mu}_{t}(r, \theta) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\theta \in\left[0, \frac{3 \pi}{4}\left[\right]\right\}+\vec{\mu}_{u}(r, \theta) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\theta \in\left[\frac{3 \pi}{4}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\left[\right]\right\}+\vec{\mu}_{\rho}(r, \theta) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, 0\left[\right.\right.\right.},\left[\frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right]\right\}}\right.}\right.}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{\mu}_{d}(r, \theta)=\left(-v \sin \theta,-v \frac{\cos \theta}{r}\right), \quad \vec{\mu}_{t}(r, \theta)=\left(-v \cos \theta, v \frac{\sin \theta}{r}\right), \\
& \vec{\mu}_{u}(r, \theta))=\left(v \sin \theta, v \frac{\cos \theta}{r}\right), \quad \vec{\mu}_{r}(r, \theta)=\left(v \cos \theta,-v \frac{\sin \theta}{r}\right), \\
& \vec{\mu}_{\rho}(r, \theta)=(-v, 0),
\end{aligned}
$$

and extended to $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$ by $2 \pi$-periodicity. The functions $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ appearing in (2.9) can be written more explicitly, using (2.10)-(2.11). For the motion on starboard tack and $\theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$, they are defined as:

$$
\mu_{1}(\theta, 1)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
-v \sin (\theta), & \\
-v, & \mu_{2}(r, \theta, 1)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
-\frac{v \cos (\theta)}{r}, & \theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{2}\left[\right.\right. \\
0, & \theta \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\left[\right.\right.\right. \\
-\frac{v \sin (\theta)}{r}, & \theta \in\left[\pi, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.\right.
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Similarly, for the motion of the boat on port tack and $\theta \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$, they are equal to:

$$
\mu_{1}(\theta,-1)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
-v, & \theta \in\left[\frac{3 \pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right],[\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, 0\left[\right.\right.\right. \\
-v \cos (\theta), & \mu_{2}(r, \theta,-1)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
v \sin (\theta), & \theta \in\left[0, \frac{3 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right. \\
\frac{v \sin (\theta)}{r}, & \theta \in\left[0, \frac{3 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.\right. \\
\frac{v \cos (\theta)}{r}, & \theta \in\left[\frac{3 \pi}{4}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\left[\right.\right.\right.
\end{array}\right.
$$

Therefore, after extending to $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$ by $2 \pi$-periodicity the coefficients $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ above, the functions below are defined:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mu_{1}(\theta, a): \mathbb{R} \times\{-1,+1\} \mapsto[-v, v] \\
& \mu_{2}(r, \theta, a): \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \times\{-1,+1\} \mapsto \mathbb{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

See Fig. 6 for the illustration of the sailing rules in polar coordinates.
Remark 2.4. A strong solution to (2.9) up to time $\tau_{f}^{a}$ is well defined because of the corresponding result in Cartesian coordinates (see Remark 2.3).

# 3 Control Problem 

In this section we introduce the control problem and prove a Verification theorem for the case $c=0$. In view of (2.9), we define the state equation as:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}^{A}=1_{\left\{R_{t}^{A}>0\right\}} \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}^{A}, A_{t}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{A}=1_{\left\{R_{t}^{A}>0\right\}} \mu_{2}\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}, A_{t}\right) d t+\sigma 1_{\left\{R_{t}^{A}>0\right\}} d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 6: Sailing rules in polar coordinates. On the left-hand side, the yacht is on port tack $(a=-1)$. On the right-hand side, the yacht is on starboard tack $(a=1)$. The flow of arrows indicates the direction of the drift. In addition to the motion along the flow, the yacht moves as a Brownian motion in a direction parallel to the $\theta$-axis, with a speed that depends on the diffusion coefficient $\sigma$. Notice that there is no Brownian component in the radial direction.
and the time to reach the target buoy $\mathbb{B}_{\eta}$ :

$$
\tau_{\eta}^{A}:=\inf \left\{t: R_{t}^{A} \leq \eta\right\}
$$

The process $\left(A_{t}\right)_{t \in[0,+\infty]}$ is an admissible strategy. Depending on the case $c=0$ or $c>0$ the definition of admissible strategy is different and, respectively, stated in Definition 3.1 or Definition 3.4 .

The position of the yacht at time $t$ driven by $A$ is defined as the $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta, a}$ strong solution $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)_{t \in\left[0, \tau_{\eta}^{A}\right]}$ of (3.1). where $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta, a}$ denotes a family of probability measures such that

$$
\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta, a}\left\{\left(R_{0}^{A}, \Theta_{0}^{A}\right)=(r, \theta), A_{0-}=a\right\}=1
$$

The initial tack $a$ is the yacht's tack just before the race starts, so $A_{0} \neq A_{0-}$ if the yacht tacks immediately after the race starts.

# 3.1 Case $c=0$ 

A strategy which allows an infinite number of tacks might reach $\mathbb{B}_{\eta}$ in a finite time. Since $c=0$, the initial tack of the boat has no influence at all on the problem, hence we will omit it in (3.3), and write $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}$.

Definition 3.1. Let $\eta>0,(r, \theta) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}$ and $A:\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} \cup\{0-\}\right) \times \Omega \mapsto\{+1,-1\}$ be a jointly measurable and adapted process in $(t, \omega)$. We say that $A$ is an admissible strategy if:

1. equation (3.1) admits a strong solution for $t \in\left[0, \tau_{\eta}^{A}\right]$,
2. $\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)<\infty$.

The set of admissible strategies under $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}$ is denoted by $\mathcal{A}_{r, \theta}^{\eta}$ (often the subscript $\cdot_{r, \theta}$ will be omitted).

In Section 4 we shall prove that, for every $\eta>0$, the set $\mathcal{A}^{\eta}$ is non empty.
The control problem $\mathcal{P}(\eta)$ consists in finding an admissible strategy that minimizes the expected time to reach the upwind buoy. Let, for $A \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$,

$$
J^{\eta}(r, \theta, A)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)
$$

Then the Value function is defined as

$$
V^{\eta}(r, \theta)=\inf _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}} J^{\eta}(r, \theta, A)
$$

In the above definition, $V^{\eta}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $J^{\eta}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \times \mathcal{A}^{\eta} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$, hence the control problem consists in finding an admissible strategy $A^{\star}$ which is optimal, that is $V^{\eta}(r, \theta)=$ $J^{\eta}\left(r, \theta, A^{\star}\right)$.

The theorem below is the so called Verification Theorem. Having a candidate Value function $\tilde{V}^{\eta}$, and a strategy $A^{\star} \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$ that is guessed to be optimal, it provides a sufficient condition for $\tilde{V}^{\eta}$ to be the Value function of the problem $\mathcal{P}(\eta)$ and for the strategy $A^{\star}$ to be optimal. Let $N^{\eta}$ be defined in the following way:

$$
N^{\eta}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, \quad N^{\eta}(t, r, \theta):=t+\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta)
$$

for some function $\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta): \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$.
Theorem 3.2. Fix $\eta>0$ and suppose there exists a continuous function $\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta): \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$ such that
(a) $\tilde{V}^{\eta}(\eta, \theta)=0$ for all $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$,
(b) $\tilde{V}^{\eta}$ is continuous at $r=\eta$, uniformly in $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$,
(c) there exist $C, D \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, such that for all $r \geq 0$, we have $\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta) \leq C r+D$.

Let $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)$ be the process defined in (3.1). If
(1) for all admissible strategies $A \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$,

$$
N^{\eta}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}, R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right)=t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}+\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right)
$$

is a submartingale, then $\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta) \leq V^{\eta}(r, \theta)$;
(2) if, in addition, there is a strategy $A^{\star} \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$ for which

$$
N^{\eta}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}, R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{\star}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{\star}\right)=t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{\star}}+\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{\star}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{\star}\right)
$$

is a martingale, then $\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta)=V^{\eta}(r, \theta)$.
Proof. Let $r$ and $\theta$ be fixed.
(1) We recall that an admissible strategy $A \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$ has the property that $\mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)<+\infty$.

The submartingale property of $N^{\eta}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}, R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right)$ implies, since $t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}$ is a bounded stopping time,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta) & =\mathbb{E}\left(N^{\eta}(0, r, \theta)\right) \leq \mathbb{E}\left(N^{\eta}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}, R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right)\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left(\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)+\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, by definition of admissible strategy, $\tau_{\eta}^{A}<\infty \mathbb{P}$-a.s., then $t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A} \rightarrow \tau_{\eta}^{A}$ a.s. as $t \rightarrow+\infty$. By the monotone convergence theorem, as $t \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)
$$

Observe that $R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A} \rightarrow R_{\tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}=\eta$ as $t \rightarrow+\infty$. By the assumption of uniform continuity at $r=\eta$, and since $V^{\eta}(\eta, \cdot)=0$, then $V^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow+\infty$.
By (2.13), we have that $\left|\mu_{1}(\theta)\right| \leq v$ for $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$. It follow that

$$
\left|R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}-r\right| \leq v\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}\right) \leq v \tau_{\eta}^{A}
$$

so

$$
R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A} \leq r+v \tau_{\eta}^{A}
$$

By assumption (c):

$$
\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right) \leq C R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}+D \leq C v \tau_{\eta}^{A}+C r+D
$$

Since $\mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)<\infty$, we can apply the dominated convergence theorem to see that, as $t \rightarrow+\infty$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A}}^{A}\right)\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

From (3.5), (3.6), (3.7), we conclude that

$$
\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta) \leq \mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)=J^{\eta}(r, \theta, A)
$$

Since this holds for all $A \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$, by taking the infimum over $A$ it follows

$$
\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta) \leq V^{\eta}(r, \theta)
$$

(2) Under the strategy $A^{*}$, (3.5) holds with the inequality replaced by an equality, hence

$$
\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta)=\mathbb{E}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}+\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}}^{A^{*}}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}}^{A^{*}}\right)\right)
$$

Using the same argument as in Item (1),

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}\left(t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}+\tilde{V}^{\eta}\left(R_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}}^{A^{*}}, \Theta_{t \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}}^{A^{*}}\right)\right)=\mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}\right)
$$

This implies

$$
\tilde{V}^{\eta}(r, \theta)=\mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}\right) \geq \inf _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}} \mathbb{E}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)=V^{\eta}(r, \theta)
$$

and by (3.8), the conclusion follows.

# 3.2 Case $c>0$ 

This is the case where the tacking cost is positive. Here a strategy cannot allow an infinite number of tacks, hence it should be piecewise constant.

Definition 3.3. Let $X_{t}:[0, \infty\left[\times \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}\right.$ be an $\left.(\mathcal{F}_{t})_{t \geq 0}\right)$ adapted and right continuous process. If, for every $\omega \in \Omega$ and $T<+\infty$, there exists $\varepsilon$ such that for all $t \in[0, T]: X_{t} \neq X_{t-}$, then $X_{r+t}=X_{t}$ for $r \in[0, \varepsilon]$, we say that $X$ is a piecewise constant process. The jump of $X_{t}$ at $t>0$ is defined as $\Delta X_{t}=X_{t}-X_{t-}$.

The yacht spends $c$ units of time when tacking. The total amount of time spent in tacking needs to be integrable for a strategy to be admissible. The main difference between Definition 3.4 and the definition of admissible strategy (see Definition 3.1) given in the case $c=0$ is the restriction to piecewise constant processes and the condition on integrability of the number of tacks, formulated in Item (c) below.

Definition 3.4. Let $\eta>0, c>0,(r, \theta) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}$ and $a \in\{-1,+1\}$. Let $A:\left(\mathbb{R}_{+} \cup\{0-\}\right) \times \Omega \mapsto$ $\{+1,-1\}$ be a piecewise constant process such that:
(a) there exists a $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta, a}$ strong solution to (3.1) in $\left[0, \tau_{\eta}^{A}\right]$, where $\tau_{\eta}^{A}$ is defined in (3.2),
(b) $\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta, a}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}\right)$ is finite,
(c) $\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta, a}\left(M_{\tau_{\eta}^{A}}(A)\right)<\infty$, where

$$
M_{t}(A)=\sum_{s=0}^{t} \Delta A_{s}
$$

The process $A$ is called an admissible strategy. The set of the admissible strategies under $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta, a}$ (defined in (3.3)) is denoted by $\mathcal{A}_{r, \theta, a}^{\mathrm{c}, \eta}$ (often the subscript $\cdot_{r, \theta, a}$ will be omitted).

In Section 4 we show that $\mathcal{A}^{c, \eta}$ is non empty.
Remark 3.5. Observe that, for $\eta>0, \mathcal{A}^{c, \eta} \subset \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$ where $\mathcal{A}^{\eta}$ is introduced in Definition 3.1.
The control problem $\mathcal{P}(c, \eta)$ consists in finding an admissible strategy that minimizes the time to reach the upwind buoy. Letting

$$
J^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a, A)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta, a}\left(\tau_{\eta}^{A}+c M_{\tau_{\eta}^{A}}(A)\right)
$$

then the Value function is defined as

$$
V^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a)=\inf _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{c, \eta}} J^{\eta}(r, \theta, a, A)
$$

In the above definition, $V^{c, \eta}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \times\{-1,+1\} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $J^{c, \eta}: \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \times\{-1,+1\} \times \mathcal{A}^{c, \eta} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, hence the control problem $\mathcal{P}(c, \eta)$ consists in finding an admissible strategy $A^{\star} \in \mathcal{A}^{c, \eta}$ such that $V^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a)=J^{c, \eta}\left(r, \theta, a, A^{\star}\right)$.

## 4 Upper bound on the Value function

In this section, we derive an analytical expression for an upper bound on the Value function (3.10). The difficulty is to prove that it is possible to reach the buoy with a finite number of tackings. Firstly, we define a particular tacking strategy and prove that the payoff (3.9) for this

strategy is bounded for any starting point. Theorem 4.14, which is the main result of the section, will be then a direct consequence of this.

Let $\alpha \in] 0, \frac{\pi}{8}]$ and $r_{0}>\eta$. We define

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
D_{1}^{1}=\left(\left[\eta, r_{0}\left\lceil\times\left(\left[-\frac{\pi}{4},-\alpha\right\rceil \cup\left[\frac{3 \pi}{2}+\alpha, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right]\right)\right.\right.\right. & , & D_{2}^{1}=\left(\left\{r_{0}\right\} \times\left(\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, 0\right\rceil \cup\left[\frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right)\right)\right.\right. \\
D_{1}^{-1}=\left(\left[\eta, r_{0}\left\lceil\times\left\lceil\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha, \pi-\alpha\right\rceil\right.\right.\right) & , & D_{2}^{-1}=\left(\left\{r_{0}\right\} \times\left\lceil\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right\rceil\right)
\end{array}
$$

and

$$
D^{1}=D_{1}^{1} \cup D_{2}^{1} \quad, \quad D^{-1}=D_{1}^{-1} \cup D_{2}^{-1}
$$

Let $C^{1}$ (resp. $C^{-1}$ ) be the complement sets of $D^{1}$ (resp. $D^{-1}$ ) in $\left[\eta, r_{0}\left\lceil\times\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}\right., \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[(\right.\right.\right.$ (see Fig. 7). We denote by $\bar{C}^{a}$ the closure of $C^{a}$. The idea of the strategy $A$ defined below is that as soon as the yacht touches the set $D^{1}$ (resp. $D^{-1}$ ) and is on starboard (resp. port) tack then it should tack. This is consistent with the definition of the forbidden lines $d^{1}$ and $d^{-1}$, see (2.1).

Suppose the initial position of the boat is $(r, \theta), \theta \in]-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}[$, with initial tack $a \in\{-1,+1\}$. Let the strategy $A$ be defined as $A_{0-}=a$, and

$$
\begin{cases}A_{0}=-1 & \text { if }(r, \theta) \in D^{1} \\ A_{0}=1 & \text { if }(r, \theta) \in D^{-1} \\ A_{0}=a & \text { elsewhere }\end{cases}
$$

Define $\left(R_{t}^{(1)}, \Theta_{t}^{(1)}\right)$ by $\left(R_{0}^{(1)}, \Theta_{0}^{(1)}\right)=(r, \theta)$, and for $t \in\left[0, \psi^{(1)}\left[\right.\right.$,

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}^{(1)}=\mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}^{(1)}, A_{0}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{(1)}=\mu_{2}\left(R_{t}^{(1)}, \Theta_{t}^{(1)}, A_{0}\right) d t+\sigma d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{(1)}:=\nu^{(1)} \wedge \rho^{(1)} \\
& \nu^{(1)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq 0:\left(R_{t}^{(1)}, \Theta_{t}^{(1)}\right) \in D_{1}^{A_{0}}\right\} \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{(1)} \\
& \rho^{(1)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq 0:\left(R_{t}^{(1)}, \Theta_{t}^{(1)}\right) \in D_{2}^{A_{0}}\right\} \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{(1)} \\
& \tau_{\eta}^{(1)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq 0: R_{t}^{(1)}=\eta\right\} \text { if }\{\cdots\} \neq \emptyset \text { else }+\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

We recall that the coefficients $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ are defined in (2.13). Then define $\left(R_{t}^{(2)}, \Theta_{t}^{(2)}\right)$ by $\left(R_{\psi^{(1)}}^{(2)}, \Theta_{\psi^{(1)}}^{(2)}\right)=\left(R_{\psi^{(1)}}^{(1)}, \Theta_{\psi^{(1)}}^{(1)}\right)$, and for $t \in\left[\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}\left[\right.\right.$

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}^{(2)}=\mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}^{(2)},-A_{0}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{(2)}=\mu_{2}\left(R_{t}^{(2)}, \Theta_{t}^{(2)},-A_{0}\right) d t+\sigma d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{(2)}:=\nu^{(2)} \wedge \rho^{(2)} \\
& \nu^{(2)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq \psi^{(1)}:\left(R_{t}^{(2)}, \Theta_{t}^{(2)}\right) \in D_{1}^{-A_{0}}\right\} \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{(2)} \\
& \rho^{(2)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq \psi^{(1)}:\left(R_{t}^{(2)}, \Theta_{t}^{(2)}\right) \in D_{2}^{-A_{0}}\right\} \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{(2)} \\
& \tau_{\eta}^{(2)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq \psi^{(1)}: R_{t}^{(2)}=\eta\right\} \text { if }\{\cdots\} \neq \emptyset \text { else }+\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

We remark that, if $\psi^{(1)}=\tau_{0}^{(1)}$, then also $\psi^{(2)}=\tau_{\eta}^{(2)}=\tau_{\eta}^{(1)}$.
Assuming $\left(R_{t}^{(i-1)}, \Theta_{t}^{(i-1)}\right)$ and $\psi^{(i-1)}, \nu^{(i-1)}, \rho^{(i-1)}, \tau_{0}^{(i-1)}$ have been defined, let $\left(R_{\psi^{(i-1)}}^{(i)}, \Theta_{\psi^{(i-1)}}^{(i)}\right)=$ $\left(R_{\psi^{(i-1)}}^{(i-1)}, \Theta_{\psi^{(i-1)}}^{(i-1)}\right)$, and for $t \in\left[\psi^{(i-1)}, \psi^{(i)}\right]$ :

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
d R_{t}^{(i)} & =\mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}^{(i)},(-1)^{i-1} A_{0}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{(i)} & =\mu_{2}\left(R_{t}^{(i)}, \Theta_{t}^{(i)},(-1)^{i-1} A_{0}\right) d t+\sigma d B_{t}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{(i)}:=\nu^{(i)} \wedge \rho^{(i)} \\
& \nu^{(i)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq \psi^{(i-1)}:\left(R_{t}^{(i)}, \Theta_{t}^{(i)}\right) \in D_{1}^{(-1)^{i-1} A_{0}}\right\} \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{(i)} \\
& \rho^{(i)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq \psi^{(i-1)}:\left(R_{t}^{(i)}, \Theta_{t}^{(i)}\right) \in D_{2}^{(-1)^{i-1} A_{0}}\right\} \wedge \tau_{\eta}^{(i)} \\
& \tau_{\eta}^{(i)}:=\inf \left\{t \geq \psi^{(i-1)}: R_{t}^{(i)}=\eta\right\} \text { if }\{\cdots\} \neq \emptyset \text { else }+\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that a strong solution to $\left(R_{t}^{(i)}, \Theta_{t}^{(i)}\right)_{t \in\left[\psi^{(i-1)}, \psi^{(i)}\right]}$ exists by Remark 2.4 since the process never hits the lines $d^{1}$ (resp. $d^{-1}$ ) when $(-1)^{i-1}=1$ (resp. $(-1)^{i-1}=-1$ ).

Let $\psi^{(0)}=0$. The process $\left(A_{t}\right)_{t \in\left[0,+\infty\right]}$ is defined by $\left(A_{t}\right)=(-1)^{i-1} A_{0}$ on $\left[\psi^{(i-1)}, \psi^{(i)}\right]$. Define

$$
\bar{i}=\inf \left\{i>0: R_{\psi^{(i)}}^{(i)}=0\right\} \text { if }\{\cdots\} \neq \emptyset \text { else }+\infty
$$

The event $\left\{\psi^{(\bar{i})}<\infty\right\}$ means that the yacht reaches the origin in a finite amount of time. Observe that, on this event, for $i \geq \bar{i}$, then $\psi^{(i)}=\psi^{(\bar{i})}$, so after tacking at $\psi^{(\bar{i}-1)}$, the yacht reaches the buoy.

The process $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)_{t \in[0, \infty[ }$ is defined as

$$
\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)= \begin{cases}{\left(R_{t}^{(i)}, \Theta_{t}^{(i)}\right) \text { for } i \leq \bar{i}, t \in\left[\psi^{(i-1)}, \psi^{(i)}\right]} & \\ {\left(0, \Theta_{\psi^{(i)}}^{(i)}\right) \text { for } t \geq \psi^{(\bar{i})}} .\end{cases}
$$

In order to show that $A$ satisfies Item (a) of Definition 3.4 we need to prove that it is piecewise continuous and that (3.1) admits a strong solution for $t \in] 0, \infty[$.

Lemma 4.1. The process $\left(A_{t}\right)$ defined above is piecewise constant. In particular there exists a strong solution to $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)_{t \in\left[0,+\infty\right]}$ defined in (4.1).

Proof. We show that $A$ is piecewise constant. Fix $\omega \in \Omega$ and $T<\infty$. In order for the strategy $A_{t}$ to switch from $\pm 1$ to $\mp 1$, it is required at least an increment greater than $\alpha$ of the Brownian motion, indeed the yacht has to cross on port tack (resp. starboard tack) the interval $\left[\frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}+\right.$ $\alpha]$ or $[-\alpha, 0]$ (resp. $\left.\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right]\right.$ or $\left.[\pi-\alpha, \pi]\right)$. In these intervals, $\mu_{2}\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t},-1\right)=0$ (resp. $\left.\mu_{2}\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t}, 1\right)=0\right)$. By uniform continuity of the path of Brownian motion in $[0, T]$, for every $\varepsilon$, there exists $\delta: \forall\left[t_{1}-t_{2}\right] \leq \delta,\left|B_{t_{i}}-B_{t_{2}}\right| \leq \varepsilon$. Let $\varepsilon=\alpha$. Then, for each $i \leq i^{T}:=\inf \left\{i: \psi_{i} \geq T\right\}$, the holding times $\psi_{i}-\psi_{i-1}$ of the strategy are larger than $\delta$ and this proves that $A$ is piecewise constant.

Since the strategy is piecewise constant and the process never hits the lines $d^{1}$ (resp. $d^{-1}$ ) when $A=1$ (resp. $A=-1$ ), there exists a strong solution to (3.1) defined by (4.1).

Remark 4.2. Now that the process $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)_{t \in[0, \infty[ }$ is defined, it is straightforward to verify that $\tau_{\eta}^{A}=\nu^{(\bar{i})}$ a.s., where the first is defined in (3.2). From now on, we will denote $\tau^{A}:=\tau_{\eta}^{A}$.

![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Figure 7: Tacking and continuation regions of the strategy $A$. The arrows indicate the direction and the intensity of the drift in the two directions $r$ and $\theta$. Each time the process hits $D^{1}$ (dark grey), $A$ tacks. We picture this by a jump to the symmetric point on $D^{-1}$ (light grey). Notice that $D^{1}$ contains the vertical segments $\left\{r_{0}\right\} \times\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, 0\right]$ and $\left\{r_{0}\right\} \times\left[\frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\right]$. The position of the yacht at the stopping times of (4.4) is depicted with bullet points.

Observe that the symmetry of the problem allows us to consider only one tack. Indeed, in Cartesian coordinates, it is clear that the payoff function (3.9) satisfies, for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$,

$$
J^{c, \eta}((x, y), 1)=J^{c, \eta}((y, x),-1)
$$

Likewise, in polar coordinates, we have, for all $(r, \theta) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$,

$$
J^{c, \eta}((r, \theta), 1)=J^{c, \eta}\left(\left\{r, \frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right\},-1\right)
$$

where $\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta$ is considered modulo $2 \pi$ in $\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$. Therefore, instead of considering two maps, one for each tack, as in Fig.6, we can consider only one map corresponding to the starboard tack. When the strategy $A$ makes the yacht tack, then the process $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)$ makes a jump in the same map so that $\Theta_{t}^{A} \in\left[-\alpha, \frac{3 \pi}{2}+\alpha\right]$ for $t \geq 0$. Namely, if $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t-1}^{A}\right) \in \partial C^{1}$, then (see Fig. 7) $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)=\left(R_{t}^{A}, \frac{\pi}{2}-\Theta_{t-1}^{A}\right)$. In particular, if $\Theta_{t}^{A}=-\alpha$ (resp. $\Theta_{t}^{A}=\frac{3 \pi}{2}+\alpha$ ), then $\Theta_{t}^{A}=\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha$ (resp $\left.\Theta_{t}^{A}=\pi-\alpha\right)$. From now on, we will consider that the yacht is always on starboard tack and as a result of which we shorten the notations. For instance, $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta, 1}$ becomes $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}$. Notice the other symmetry condition given by

$$
J^{c, \eta}((r, \theta), 1)=J^{c, \eta}\left(\left(r, \frac{3 \pi}{2}-\theta\right), 1\right), \quad \forall(r, \theta) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.
$$

where $\frac{3 \pi}{2}-\theta$ is considered modulo $2 \pi$ in $\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{7 \pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$.
We now define some stopping times which will be used in the proof of Lemmas 4.6, 4.8, 4.9. Recall that $\tau^{A}$ is defined in Remark 4.2.
Definition 4.3. Let $\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right)$ denote the position of a yacht driven by $A$. We set $\sigma_{0}=\nu_{0}=$ $\rho_{0}=\psi_{0}=0, E_{0}=\emptyset$ and for all $i \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$, we define

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{i} & =\inf \left\{t \geq \psi_{i-1}: \Theta_{t}^{A} \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, 0\right]\right\} \wedge \tau^{A} \\
\nu_{i} & =\inf \left\{t \geq \psi_{i-1}:\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right) \in D_{1}^{1}\right\} \wedge \tau^{A} \\
\rho_{i} & =\inf \left\{t \geq \psi_{i-1}:\left(R_{t}^{A}, \Theta_{t}^{A}\right) \in D_{2}^{1}\right\} \wedge \tau^{A} \\
\psi_{i} & =\nu_{i} \wedge \rho_{i} \\
u_{i} & =\psi_{i}-\psi_{i-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
E_{i}=\left\{\sup _{\psi_{i-1} \leq t \leq \tau^{A}}\left|\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{\psi_{i-1}}\right|<\frac{\alpha}{2}\right\} \subset \Omega
$$

Observe that, once the process $\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t}\right)$ is defined as in (4.1), then $\nu_{i}=\nu^{(i)}, \rho_{i}=\rho^{(i)}$, $\psi_{i}=\psi^{(i)}$ a.s.

The stopping times of (4.4) are illustrated in Fig.7. The times $\psi_{i}$ are the tacking times of the strategy $A$ and the event $E_{i}$ means that after the $(i-1)$-th tacking, the wind is calm (i.e. varies by no more than $\frac{\alpha}{2}$ ) until the end of the race.
Remark 4.4. By definition, $\psi_{i} \leq \tau^{A}$ and if $\left\{\psi_{i}=\tau^{A}\right\}$ occurs, then $E_{i+1}$ occurs trivially.
Remark 4.5. Below Lemmas 4.6, 4.8, 4.9 and Corollary 4.10, 4.11 altogether tell us that, if from a tacking time $\psi_{i-1}$, the wind is calm for a sufficiently long time (that is $E_{i}$ occurs), then the yacht will reach the buoy with at most one tacking and in a bounded time. Moreover, if the wind is calm, then the yacht will never be pushed backwards into the circle $r=r_{0}$.

Lemma 4.6. There exists $K \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$such that for all $i \in \mathbb{N}$ and for all $(r, \theta) \in \bar{C}^{1}$, the holding times $u_{i}$ of the strategy $A$ defined in (4.4) satisfy

$$
\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(u_{i}\right) \leq K<+\infty
$$

Moreover, the stopping times $\sigma_{i}, \nu_{i}$ and $\psi_{i}$ defined in (4.4) are integrable.
Proof. Let $(r, \theta) \in \bar{C}^{1}$ be given numbers and let $f(x)=\left(x-\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right)^{2}$. Then by Itô's formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(\Theta_{i \wedge \nu_{1}}^{A}\right)-f(\theta)= & \int_{0}^{t \wedge \nu_{1}} 2 \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}^{A}, \Theta_{s}^{A}, 1\right)\left(\Theta_{s}^{A}-\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right) d s \\
& +2 \sigma \int_{0}^{t \wedge \nu_{1}}\left(\Theta_{s}^{A}-\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right) d B_{s}+\sigma^{2}\left(t \wedge \nu_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

On one hand, $\Theta_{t}^{A}$ is bounded. On the other hand, for all $(r, \theta) \in \bar{C}^{1}, f(\theta) \leq\left(-\alpha-\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right)^{2}$ and $\mu_{2}(r, \theta, 1)\left(\theta-\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right) \geq 0$ (see (2.12)). Hence, taking the expectation in the previous equation and using these inequalities, we find that $\sigma^{2} \mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(t \wedge \nu_{1}\right) \leq 2\left(\alpha+\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right)^{2}$. Therefore, by the monotone convergence theorem, we find that

$$
\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\nu_{1}\right) \leq 2 \sigma^{-2}\left(\alpha+\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right)^{2}=: K
$$

Observe that by definition of these stopping times, $\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(u_{1}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{1}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\rho_{1} \wedge \nu_{1}\right) \leq \mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\nu_{1}\right)$. Furthermore, by the strong Markov property, we have for all $i \in \mathbb{N}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(u_{i}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(u_{i} \mid \mathcal{F}_{\psi_{i-1}}\right)\right)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\mathbb{E}_{R_{\psi_{i-1}}^{A}, \Theta_{\psi_{i-1}}^{A}}\left(u_{1}\right)\right) \leq K
$$

Finally, $\nu_{i}, \psi_{i}, \sigma_{i} \leq \sum_{n=1}^{i} u_{i}$. Thus, all these stopping times are of finite expectation.
Remark 4.7. A consequence of this lemma is that, without loss of generality, we can consider initial conditions $(r, \theta)$ such that $r \leq r_{0}$ and $\left.\theta \in\right] \frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha]$. Indeed, with at most one tacking and in a time with finite expectation, using (4.2), the yacht will be at

$$
\left(R_{\psi_{1}}^{A}, \Theta_{\psi_{1}}^{A}\right) \in\left(\left[\eta, r_{0}\left[\times\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha, \pi-\alpha\right\}\right) \cup\left(\left\{r_{0}\right\} \times\left(\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right] \cup[\pi-\alpha, \pi]\right)\right)\right.\right.
$$

Moreover, by symmetry (see (4.3)), we can assume that

$$
\left(R_{\psi_{1}}^{A}, \Theta_{\psi_{1}}^{A}\right) \in\left(\left[\eta, r_{0}\left[\times\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right\}\right) \cup\left(\left\{r_{0}\right\} \times\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right]\right)\right.\right.
$$

and this set is clearly included in $\left[\eta, r_{0}\right] \times\left[\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right]$. From now on, we will denote

$$
\mathcal{S}:=\left[\eta, r_{0}\right] \times\left[\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right]
$$

Next two lemmas prove bounds on the stopping times introduced in (4.4). Moreover, they show that, if the wind is calm, that is $E_{1}$ occurs, then the yacht is never pushed backwards into the circle of radius $r_{0}$.

Lemma 4.8. If $\zeta$ denotes the following stopping time

$$
\zeta=\inf \left\{t \geq 0: \Theta_{t}^{A} \notin\left[\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha, \frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha\right]\right\} \wedge \tau^{A}
$$

then, for all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$,

$$
R_{t}^{A} \leq r, \quad t \in[0, \zeta] \quad \text { and } \quad \zeta \leq \frac{r-\eta}{v \cos \alpha}, \quad \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta} \text {-almost surely: }
$$

Proof. By (2.12), we have for all $0 \leq t \leq \zeta$ that $\mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}^{A}, 1\right) \in[-v,-v \cos \alpha]$. Hence,

$$
\eta \leq R_{t \wedge \zeta}^{A}=r+\int_{0}^{t \wedge \zeta} \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{s}^{A}, 1\right) d s \leq r-v \cos \alpha(t \wedge \zeta), \quad \forall t \geq 0
$$

Therefore, $R_{t}^{A} \leq r$, for $t \in[0, \zeta]$, and $\zeta \leq \frac{r-\eta}{v \cos \alpha}$.
Lemma 4.9. If the event $E_{1}$ occurs, then for all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$, the following inequalities hold $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}$-almost surely.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sigma_{1}-\zeta \leq \frac{d_{1} r}{v} \\
& \psi_{1}-\sigma_{1} \leq \frac{d_{2} R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}}{v}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
d_{1}=\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) \tan \alpha+1, \quad d_{2}=\frac{\left(\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)+\tan \alpha\right) \cos \alpha}{\cos (2 \alpha)}
$$

Moreover,

$$
R_{t}^{A} \leq r, \quad t \in\left[0, \psi_{1}\right]
$$

Proof. In order to establish this statement, we will treat three cases separately.
Case 1: $R_{\zeta}^{A}=\eta$ (which is equivalent to $\zeta=\tau^{A}$ ). If $\zeta=\tau^{A}$, then $M_{\tau^{A}}(A)=0$, $\sigma_{1}=\nu_{1}=\rho_{1}=\psi_{1}=\tau^{A}$ and since $R_{\tau^{A}}^{A}=\eta$, the two inequalities are satisfied and (4.7) follows from Lemma 4.8.

Case 2: $\Theta_{\zeta}^{A}=\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha$ and $R_{\zeta}^{A}>\eta$. Then, on the event $E_{1}$, we have, for all $t \geq \zeta$, that $\Theta_{t}^{A} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$. Indeed, if we set

$$
\kappa= \begin{cases}\inf _{+ \infty}\left\{t \geq \zeta: \Theta_{t}^{A} \notin\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]\right\}, & \text { if }\{\cdots\} \neq \emptyset \\ +\infty, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

then, by (2.12) and (2.9), on $\{\kappa<+\infty\}$,

$$
\Theta_{\kappa}^{A}=\Theta_{\zeta}^{A}+\int_{\zeta}^{\kappa} \underbrace{\mu_{2}\left(R_{s}^{A}, \Theta_{s}^{A}, 1\right)}_{=0, \text { since } s<\kappa} d s+\underbrace{\sigma B_{\kappa}}_{|\cdot|<\frac{\alpha}{2}}-\underbrace{\sigma B_{\zeta}}_{|\cdot|<\frac{\alpha}{2}}>\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha-2 \frac{\alpha}{2}=\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

and similarly,

$$
\Theta_{\kappa}^{A}<\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha+2 \frac{\alpha}{2}=\frac{\pi}{2}+2 \alpha<\pi
$$

Since $\Theta_{\kappa}^{A} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$ on $\{\kappa<+\infty\}$, this shows that $\mathbb{P}\{\kappa<+\infty\}=0$ and therefore, $\kappa \equiv+\infty$. It follows that $\Theta_{t}^{A} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$ for all $t \geq \zeta$. We have then by (2.12) that for all $t \geq \zeta$,

$$
R_{t \wedge \tau^{A}}^{A}=R_{\zeta}^{A}+\int_{\zeta}^{t \wedge \tau^{A}} \underbrace{\mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{\tau}^{A}, 1\right)}_{=-v} d s=R_{\zeta}^{A}-v\left(t \wedge \tau^{A}-\zeta\right)
$$

Taking the limit when $t \rightarrow+\infty$, we find that $\tau^{A}-\zeta \leq \frac{R_{\tau}^{A}-\eta}{c} \leq \frac{r}{\zeta}$ by Lemma 4.8. Furthermore, since $\kappa=+\infty$, we have $\psi_{1}=\sigma_{1}=\nu_{1}=\rho_{1}=\tau^{A}$ and $R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A^{c}}=\eta \leq r$. Thus, the two inequalities (4.6a), (4.6b) are also satisfied in this case. By (4.8), it follows that $R_{t}^{A} \leq R_{\zeta}^{A} \leq r$ for $t \in\left[\zeta, \psi_{1}\right]$, where the last inequality follows from Lemma 4.8, hence also (4.7) is proved.

Case 3: $\Theta_{\zeta}^{A}=\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha$ and $R_{\zeta}^{A}>\eta$. On $E_{1}$, we can show similarly as in the previous case that

$$
\Theta_{t}^{A} \in\left[-\alpha, \frac{\pi}{2}[, \quad \text { for all } t \in\left[\zeta, \psi_{1}\right[ .\right.
$$

Therefore, by Prop 2.1 and by (2.2), since the yacht is in zone $I \cup I V^{a}$, in Cartesian coordinates the process $\vec{X}_{t}^{A}$ satisfies for all $t \in\left[\zeta, \psi_{1}\right[$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& X_{t}^{A}=\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) X_{\zeta}^{A}-\sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) Y_{\zeta}^{A}+v \int_{\zeta}^{t} \sin \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s \\
& Y_{t}^{A}=\sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) X_{\zeta}^{A}+\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) Y_{\zeta}^{A}-v \int_{\zeta}^{t} \cos \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

On $E_{1},\left|\sigma B_{t}\right|<\frac{\alpha}{2}$ for all $t \leq \tau^{A}$, thus, we can bound $Y_{t}^{A}$ in the second equation as follows

$$
-\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) X_{\zeta}^{A}+\cos \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) Y_{\zeta}^{A}-v(t-\zeta)<Y_{t}^{A}<\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) X_{\zeta}^{A}+Y_{\zeta}^{A}-v(t-\zeta) \cos \alpha
$$

for all $t \in\left[\zeta, \psi_{1}\left[\right.\right.$. Replacing $X_{\zeta}^{A}=R_{\zeta}^{A} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha\right)=R_{\zeta}^{A} \sin \alpha$ and $Y_{\zeta}^{A}=R_{\zeta}^{A} \cos \alpha$ in the above equation, we get

$$
\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right) R_{\zeta}^{A}-v(t-\zeta)<Y_{t}^{A}<\left(\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) \sin \alpha+\cos \alpha\right) R_{\zeta}^{A}-v(t-\zeta) \cos \alpha
$$

Observe that, on $E_{1}$ and under our assumptions, $Y_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}=C \geq 0$, for a costant $C$ depending on $\omega \in \Omega$. Strict inequality corresponds to the yacht hitting the buoy before the line $y=0$, that is $\sigma_{1}=\tau^{A}$. Setting $t=\sigma_{1}$ and adding $v(t-\zeta) \cos \alpha$ to (4.10), the second inequality becomes

$$
v\left(\sigma_{1}-\zeta\right)<d_{1} R_{\zeta}^{A}-\frac{C}{\cos \alpha}
$$

We have thus, by Lemma 4.8, that $\sigma_{1}-\zeta<\frac{d_{1} r}{r}$ and this establishes inequality (4.6a) of the statement. Notice that if $\sigma_{1}=\tau^{A}$, then $\psi_{1}=\nu_{1}=\rho_{1}=\tau^{A}, R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}=\eta$ and (4.6b) is trivial, so from now on, we assume $\sigma_{1}<\tau^{A}$.

On $E_{1}$, since $X_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}=R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}$ and $Y_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}=0$, we have for all $t \in\left[\sigma_{1}, \psi_{1}\left[\right.\right.$, by Prop 2.1 and by (2.2), since the yacht is in zone $I V^{\alpha}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
X_{t}^{A} & =\cos \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}+v \int_{\sigma_{1}}^{t} \sin \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s \\
Y_{t}^{A} & =\sin \left(\sigma B_{t}\right) R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}-v \int_{\sigma_{1}}^{t} \cos \left(\sigma B_{t}-\sigma B_{s}\right) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

and so $X_{t}^{A} \leq R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}+v\left(t-\sigma_{1}\right) \sin \alpha$ and

$$
-\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}-v\left(t-\sigma_{1}\right) \leq Y_{t}^{A} \leq \sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}-v\left(t-\sigma_{1}\right) \cos \alpha
$$

Since on this time interval, $X_{t}^{A} \tan \alpha+Y_{t}^{A}>0$, we find by combining these inequalities that

$$
0<X_{t}^{A} \tan \alpha+Y_{t}^{A} \leq R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\left(\tan \alpha+\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)\right)+v\left(t-\sigma_{1}\right)\left(\tan \alpha \sin \alpha-\cos \alpha\right)
$$

which provides

$$
t-\sigma_{1} \leq \frac{R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}}{v} \frac{\tan \alpha+\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)}{\cos \alpha-\tan \alpha \sin \alpha}=\frac{R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}}{v} d_{2}
$$

by definition of $d_{2}$. Taking the limit $t \rightarrow \psi_{1}$, we obtain inequality (4.6b) of the statement.
We now prove inequality (4.7). By (4.9) and (2.12), on $E_{1}$, for all $t \in\left[\zeta, \psi_{1}\left[, R_{t}^{A}\right.\right.$ satisfies

$$
d R_{t}^{A}=-v \sin \left(\Theta_{t}^{A}\right) d t=-v \frac{Y_{t}^{A}}{R_{t}^{A}} d t
$$

Hence, we have

$$
d\left(R_{t}^{A}\right)^{2}=2 R_{t}^{A} d R_{t}^{A}=-2 v Y_{t}^{A} d t
$$

and by $(4.10)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(R_{t}^{A}\right)^{2} & \leq\left(R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2}-2 v \int_{\zeta}^{t}\left(\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right) R_{\zeta}^{A}-v(s-\zeta)\right) d s \\
& =\left(R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2}+\left(v(t-\zeta)-\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right) R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2}-\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right)\left(R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Setting $t=\sigma_{1}$ and using (4.11), we get by Lemma 4.8

$$
\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2} \leq\left(R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2}+\left(d_{1} R_{\zeta}^{A}-\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right) R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2}-\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right)\left(R_{\zeta}^{A}\right)^{2} \leq r^{2} c_{1}^{2}
$$

where $c_{1}=\sqrt{1+\left(d_{1}-\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right)\right)^{2}-\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right)}$. Moreover, by (4.15), we have that on $E_{1}$, for all $t \in\left[\sigma_{1}, \psi_{1}\left[\right.\right.$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(R_{t}^{A}\right)^{2} & =\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2}-2 v \int_{\sigma_{1}}^{t} Y_{s}^{A} d s \\
\text { (by (4.12)) } & \leq\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2}+2 v \int_{\sigma_{1}}^{t}\left(\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}+v\left(s-\sigma_{1}\right)\right) d s \\
& =\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2}+\left(\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}+v\left(t-\sigma_{1}\right)\right)^{2}-\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2} \\
\text { (by (4.13)) } & \leq\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2}\left(1+\left(\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)+d_{2}\right)^{2}-\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)\right)=\left(R_{\sigma_{1}}^{A}\right)^{2} c_{2}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $c_{2}=\sqrt{1+\left(d_{2}+\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)\right)^{2}-\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)}$. Since the process $R_{t}^{A}$ is continuous, this inequality remains true for $t=\psi_{1}$.

The last assertion (4.7) is true for $t \in[0, \zeta]$ by Lemma 4.8. For $t \in\left[\zeta, \sigma_{1}\right]$, (4.7) follows from (4.14) since $\sin \left(\Theta_{t}^{A}\right)>0$. Finally, for $t \in\left[\sigma_{1}, \psi_{1}\right]$, (4.16) and (4.17) imply that $R_{t}^{A} \leq c_{1} c_{2} r$. Long but direct computations show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{1}^{2} c_{2}^{2}= & \frac{1}{2}(1+\cos \alpha+2((1+\cos \alpha \sec (2 \alpha)) \sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)+\sec (2 \alpha) \sin (\alpha))^{2}) \\
& \times\left(1-\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(1-\cos \left(\frac{3 \alpha}{2}\right)+\sin \left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right) \tan \alpha\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\sec =\frac{1}{\cos }$. Furthermore, it can be shown that the term on the right-hand side is an increasing and positive function of $\alpha \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$ approximately equal to 0.72 at $\frac{\pi}{8}$. Since we assumed that $\alpha \leq \frac{\pi}{8}$, we conclude that $c_{1} c_{2}<1$ and this concludes the proof.

The Corollary below proves that, if at some point of the race the wind is calm, then the yacht reaches the origin with at most one additional tack. We recall that the region $\mathcal{S}$ is defined in (4.5).

Corollary 4.10. For all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$ and $i \in \mathbb{N}$, if $E_{i}$ occurs then $\nu_{i}=\psi_{i} \leq \tau^{A}=\psi_{i+1}$ and $M_{\tau^{A}}(A) \leq i \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta^{-}}$-a.s. Moreover, if $\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}$, then $\Theta_{\psi_{i}}^{A}=\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha$.

Proof. By construction, at time $\psi_{i-1}$, the yacht is in $\mathcal{S}$. If $\psi_{i}=\tau^{A}$ the proof is trivial, so we assume $\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}$, hence we are in the situation described by case 3 of the proof of Lemma 4.9. By (4.7) and by the strong Markov property, we have that $R_{t}^{A}<r_{0}, \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta^{-}}$ a.s. for all $t \in\left[\psi_{i-1}, \psi_{i}\right]$ on $E_{i}$. Thus, at time $\psi_{i}-$ the yacht hits the line $\theta=-\alpha, \nu_{i}<\rho_{i}$ and $\Theta_{\psi_{i}}^{A}=\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha$. Again by the strong Markov property, this configuration is equivalent to the case 2 of the proof of Lemma 4.9. Therefore, on $E_{i}$, in this case we have that $\sigma_{i+1}=\nu_{i+1}=\psi_{i+1}=\tau^{A}$ and so $M_{\tau^{A}}(A) \leq i$.

Corollary 4.11. If $E_{1}$ occurs then, for all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$,

$$
\tau^{A}<(\sec \alpha+1) \frac{r_{0}-\eta}{v}+\left(d_{1}+d_{2}\right) \frac{r_{0}}{v}=: \Gamma, \quad \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta^{-}} \text {-almost surely. }
$$

Proof. Indeed, on $E_{1}$, we have by the preceding corollary that $M_{\tau^{A}}(A) \leq 1$. If $\psi_{1}<\tau^{A}$, then $\nu_{1}=\psi_{1}$ and $\Theta_{\psi_{1}}^{A}=\frac{\pi}{2}+\alpha$. Thus, by Lemma 4.8 and Lemma 4.9,

$$
\tau^{A}=\zeta+\left(\sigma_{1}-\zeta\right)+\left(\psi_{1}-\sigma_{1}\right)+\left(\tau^{A}-\psi_{1}\right) \leq \frac{r_{0}-\eta}{v \cos \alpha}+\frac{d_{1} r_{0}}{v}+\frac{d_{2} r_{0}}{v}+\left(\tau^{A}-\psi_{1}\right), \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta^{-}} \text {-a.s.. }
$$

Furthermore, on $E_{1}, \Theta_{t}^{A} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$ for all $t \in\left[\psi_{1}, \tau^{A}\right]$, hence $R_{t}^{A}=R_{\psi_{1}}^{A}-v\left(t-\psi_{1}\right)$ and

$$
\tau^{A}-\psi_{1}=\frac{R_{\psi_{1}}^{A}-R_{\tau^{A}}^{A}}{v}=\frac{R_{\psi_{1}}^{A}-\eta}{v}<\frac{r_{0}-\eta}{v}
$$

The case $\psi_{1}=\tau^{A}$ follows from above.
Proposition 4.12. There exists $p_{0} \in] 0,1[$, depending only on the parameters $\alpha, \sigma, v$ and $r_{0}$, such that for all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$,
(a) $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{2}=\tau^{A}\right) \geq p_{0}$,
(b) $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right) \leq\left(1-p_{0}\right)^{\left\lfloor\frac{i}{2}\right\rfloor}$ for all $i \in \mathbb{N}, i \geq 2$.

Proof. (a) Observe that by Corollary 4.10, $E_{1} \subset\left\{\psi_{2}=\tau^{A}\right\}$. Thus, by Corollary 4.11,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{2}=\tau^{A}\right) & \geq \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(E_{1}\right)=\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\sup _{0 \leq t \leq \tau^{A}}\left|\sigma B_{t}\right|<\frac{a}{2}\right) \\
& \geq \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\sup _{0 \leq t \leq \Gamma}\left|\sigma B_{t}\right|<\frac{a}{2}\right)=: p_{0}>0
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Notice that $\left\{\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right\} \subset\left\{\psi_{i-1}<\tau^{A}\right\} \subset \cdots \subset\left\{\psi_{1}<\tau^{A}\right\}$, so by the strong Markov property and the previous point, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\left\{\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right\} \cap\left\{\psi_{i-2}<\tau^{A}\right\}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\mathbf{1}_{\left\{\psi_{i-2}<\tau^{A}\right\}} \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{i}<\tau^{A} \mid \mathcal{F}_{\psi_{i-2}}\right)\right) \\
& \leq \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{i-2}<\tau^{A}\right)\left(1-p_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

If $i$ is even, the induction is stopped at $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{2}<\tau^{A}\right)$ and claim follows. If $i$ is odd, the induction is stopped at $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{3}<\tau^{A}\right)$ and the conclusion follows after remarking that $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{3}<\tau^{A}\right) \leq$ $\mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{2}<\tau^{A}\right)$.

Proposition 4.13. For all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$,
(a) $\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(M_{\tau^{A}}(A)\right)<\frac{2}{p_{0}}-1$,
(b) $\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\tau^{A}\right)<K \frac{2}{p_{0}}$,
where $K$ is the constant defined in Lemma 4.6.
Proof. (a) Notice that $\left\{M_{\tau^{A}}(A)>i\right\} \subset\left\{\psi_{i+1}<\tau^{A}\right\}$, thus, we have, by Prop. 4.12

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(M_{\tau^{A}}(A)\right) & =\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(M_{\tau^{A}}(A)>i\right) \leq \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{i+1}<\tau^{A}\right) \\
& \leq 1+\sum_{i=2}^{\infty} \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left(\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right) \leq 1+\sum_{i=2}^{\infty}\left(1-p_{0}\right)^{\left\lfloor\frac{i}{2}\right\rfloor}=\frac{2}{p_{0}}-1
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\tau^{A}\right) & =\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\sum_{i=0}^{M_{\tau^{A}}(A)} u_{i+1}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \sum_{i=0}^{k} u_{i+1} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{M_{\tau^{A}}(A)=k\right\}}\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\sum_{k=i}^{\infty} u_{i+1} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{M_{\tau^{A}}(A)=k\right\}}\right)=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(u_{i+1} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{M_{\tau^{A}}(A) \geq i\right\}}\right) \\
& \leq \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(\mathbb{E}_{r, \theta}\left(u_{i+1} \mid \mathcal{F}_{\psi_{i}}\right) \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right\}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, by the strong Markov property and by Lemma 4.6, we find that the right-hand side is smaller than

$$
K \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\left\{\psi_{i}<\tau^{A}\right\} \leq K\left(2+\sum_{i=2}^{\infty}\left(1-p_{0}\right)^{\left\lfloor\frac{i}{2}\right\rfloor}\right)=K \frac{2}{p_{0}}
$$

and the proof of Item (b) is complete.

The Theorem below is the main result of the section. As a side result, it also proves an upper bound on the Value function (3.4), for the case $c=0$, which will be improved in the next section, where the optimal strategy is conjectured. We recall that $V^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a)$ (resp. $V^{\eta}(r, \theta)$ ) is defined in (3.10) (resp. (3.4)).

Theorem 4.14. For every $\eta>0, c \geq 0$ and every $(r, \theta, a) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R} \times\{ \pm 1\}, A \in \mathcal{A}_{r, \theta}^{\eta} \cap \mathcal{A}_{r, \theta, a}^{c, \eta}$. In particular,
(a) $V^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a) \leq K\left(1+\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)+c\left(1+\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)$,
(b) $V^{\eta}(r, \theta) \leq K\left(1+\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)$,
where $K$ is the constant defined in Lemma 4.6.
Proof. Let $r_{0}>r$. Proposition 4.13 shows that the strategy $A$ satisfies

$$
J^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a, A) \leq K \frac{2}{p_{0}}+c\left(\frac{2}{p_{0}}-1\right)
$$

for all $(r, \theta) \in \mathcal{S}$ and $a=1$. Remark 4.7 tells us that if the initial conditions are different, i.e. $a=1$ and $(r, \theta) \in C^{1}$, it is a matter of one tacking and of a finite expectation time to be in the initial configuration, so $J^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a, A) \leq K\left(1+\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)+c\left(\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)$. If $a=-1$ and $(r, \theta) \in C^{-1}$, then symmetry (4.2) tells us that it is equivalent to consider $a=1$ and $\left(r, \frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right)$, which is in $C^{1}$. Finally, if $a=1$ and $(r, \theta) \in D^{1}$ (resp. $a=-1$ and $(r, \theta) \in D^{-1}$ ), the yacht tacks immediately, so $J^{c, \eta}(r, \theta, a, A) \leq K\left(1+\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)+c\left(1+\frac{2}{p_{0}}\right)$. This proves Item a) and together with Lemma 4.1, shows that $A \in \mathcal{A}_{r, \theta, a}^{c, \eta}$ for all $\eta>0,(r, \theta) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}, a \in\{+1,-1\}$. Using Remark 3.5, it also follows that $A \in \mathcal{A}_{r, \theta}^{\eta}$. Item (b) follows from Item a) after discarding the tacking cost.

# 5 Conjectured optimal strategy for $\eta>0$ and $c=0$ 

The strategy studied in the previous section, while it allowed to prove that the Value function is finite in both cases $c>0$ and $c=0$, is suboptimal for the latter one. Indeed, for example, if $\Theta_{t} \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{4}[, \right.$ depending of the path of the boat, there is a positive probability that $A_{t}=1$. The boat, in this event, would proceed at speed $v \sin \left(\Theta_{t}\right)$ towards the buoy, while if $A_{t}=-1$ the speed would be $v \cos \left(\Theta_{t}\right)$.

We hypothesize that the optimal strategy, in the case of null tacking cost, involves a feedback approach, selecting, at any given position of the race field, the tack that maximizes the projection of the boat's speed along the radial direction. We prove that it is an admissible strategy in the sense of Definition 3.1. The coefficients of the state equation are not Lipschitz, hence standard results cannot be applied, but they exhibit a monotonicity property which allows to prove strong uniqueness and apply the Yamada-Watanabe argument. In a companion paper it will be shown that it is indeed optimal.

### 5.1 Definition of the strategy

Let $\eta>0$ and $(r, \theta)$ be the initial fixed starting point. The conjectured optimal strategy has the following form.

Let $A_{0-}^{\star}(\theta)=a$ for a given $a \in\{-1,+1\}$. We recall that, since we are in the setting $c=0$, the initial tack has no influence. Then for $t \geq 0, A^{*}$ is defined as the feedback strategy

![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Figure 8: On the left, guessed optimal strategy $A^{*}$. The arrows indicate the direction of the optimal drift, and the dashed ones the direction of the drift under the strategy $-A^{*}$. On the right, drift of the processes $R^{A^{*}}, \Theta^{A^{*}}$ extended to $\mathbb{R}$ by $2 \pi$-periodicity.
$A_{t}^{*}(\omega):=a^{*}\left(\Theta_{t}(\omega)\right)$, where

$$
a^{*}(\theta)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
1, & \theta \in\left[\frac{\pi}{4} ; \frac{5 \pi}{4}\right], \\
-1, & \theta \in\left[\frac{7.3 \pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{4}\right],
\end{array}\right.
$$

and then extended on $\mathbb{R}$ by $2 \pi$-periodicity. See also Fig. 8 for a visual interpretation. Under the strategy $A^{*}$, system (3.1) becomes

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}^{A^{*}}=1_{\left\{R_{t}^{A^{*}}>0\right\}} \mu_{1}^{*}\left(\Theta_{t}^{A^{*}}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{A^{*}}=1_{\left\{R_{t}^{A^{*}}>0\right\}} \mu_{2}^{*}\left(R_{t}^{A^{*}}, \Theta_{t}^{A^{*}}\right) d t+\sigma 1_{\left\{R_{t}^{A^{*}}>0\right\}} d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where, since for $\theta \in\left[\frac{\pi}{4} ; \frac{5 \pi}{4}\right[$ the yacht sails on starboard tack,

$$
\mu_{1}^{*}(\theta):=\mu_{1}(\theta, 1), \quad \mu_{2}^{*}(r, \theta):=\mu_{2}(r, \theta, 1)
$$

and for $\theta \in\left[-\frac{2 \pi}{4} ; \frac{\pi}{4}\left[\right.\right.$, the yacht is on port tack, therefore

$$
\mu_{1}^{*}(\theta):=\mu_{1}(\theta,-1), \quad \mu_{2}^{*}(r, \theta):=\mu_{2}(r, \theta,-1)
$$

The functions $\mu_{1}^{*}, \mu_{2}^{*}$ are then extended to $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$ by $2 \pi$-periodicity. We recall the definition of $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ in (2.13).

# 5.2 Existence of the process controlled by $A^{*}$, case $\eta \geq 0$ 

Proving the existence and uniqueness of a solution of the system (5.4) controlled by the process $A^{*}$ requires some care, because the function $\theta_{0} \rightarrow \mu_{2}(r, \theta)$ has discontinuities at $G:=\cup_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} G_{k}$, where $G_{k}=\left\{\frac{\pi}{4}+k \pi\right\}$, therefore standard results do not apply. In the present situation the coefficients satisfy a monotonicity property, see (5.5), but even the results in literature which rely on this property assume continuity of the coefficients in the spatial coordinates, and hence are not applicable, see for example [7, Sec. 3]. Our proof uses the classical Yamada-Watanabe procedure, therefore we first prove pathwise uniqueness, and then the existence of a weak solution.

Proposition 5.1. Let $\eta>0$. For every $(r, \theta) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}$ there exists a unique strong solution to (5.1) on $[0, T]$, for any $T>0$. Moreover $\tau_{0}^{A^{*}} \leq \sqrt{2} \frac{(r-\eta)}{r}$ a.s. In particular, $A^{*}$ is an admissible strategy, that is $A^{*} \in \mathcal{A}^{\eta}$.

Proof. Observe that, at or before an arbitrary time $T>0$, the boat can be close to the origin, where the coefficient $\mu_{2}^{*}$ blows up. For this reason, we first introduce the state equation below with damped coefficients. Define, for $n \geq n^{\eta}:=\inf \left\{n>0: \frac{1}{n}<\eta\right\}$,

$$
\phi_{n}(x):= \begin{cases}0, & \text { if } x \leq \eta-\frac{1}{\mathrm{p}}, \\ n(x-\eta)+1, & \text { if } x \in] \eta-\frac{\mathrm{p}}{n}, \eta[ \\ 1, & \text { if } x \geq \eta\end{cases}
$$

and consider the system of SDEs

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}^{n, A^{*}}=\phi_{n}\left(R_{t}^{n, A^{*}}\right) \mu_{1}^{*}\left(\Theta_{t}^{n, A^{*}}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}^{n, A^{*}}=\phi_{n}\left(R_{t}^{n, A^{*}}\right) \mu_{2}^{*}\left(R_{t}^{n, A^{*}}, \Theta_{t}^{n, A^{*}}\right) d t+\phi_{n}\left(R_{t}^{n, A^{*}}\right) \sigma d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Define also the stopping time $\tau_{\eta}^{n, A^{*}}:=\inf \left\{t: R_{t}^{n, A^{*}} \leq \eta\right\}$. Observe that $\tau_{\eta}^{n, A^{*}}$ does not depend on $n$ even if the process involved in its definition does. This is due to the fact that $\phi_{n}(r)=1$ for $r \geq \eta$. Therefore, if there exists a unique strong solution to (5.4) for $t \in[0, T]$ and any $T>0$, and in addition $\tau^{n, A^{*}}$ is bounded, then $\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}=\tau_{\eta}^{n, A^{*}}$ a.s.

We first prove the existence of a strong solution to (5.4) for $t \in[0, T], n \geq n^{\eta}$. Then, by a standard localization procedure, the existence and uniqueness of a strong solution to (5.1) follows for $t \in\left[0, \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}\right]$ and $\mathbb{P}\left[\left(R_{t}^{A^{*}}, T_{t}^{A^{*}}\right)=\left(R_{t}^{n, A^{*}}, \Theta_{t}^{n, A^{*}}\right), t \in\left[0, \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}\right)\right]=1$. In the sequel, we will write $\mu_{1}(\theta)$ for $\mu_{1}(\theta)^{*}$ and $\mu_{2}(r, \theta)$ for $\mu_{2}(r, \theta)^{*}$.

The first step is to prove that $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ satisfy the monotonicity condition below

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(\binom{r_{1}}{\theta_{1}}-\binom{r_{2}}{\theta_{2}}\right) \cdot\left(\binom{\phi_{n}\left(r_{1}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}{\phi_{n}\left(r_{1}\right) \mu_{2}\left(r_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)}\right)-\binom{\phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\theta_{2}\right)}{\phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right) \mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)}\right) \\
\leq C_{n}\left[\left(r_{1}-r_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

where $C_{n}$ is a constant depending on $n$. In fact, (5.5) can be rewritten as

$$
\left(r_{1}-r_{2}\right)\left(\phi_{n}\left(r_{1}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\theta_{1}\right)-\phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\theta_{2}\right)\right)+\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\phi_{n}\left(r_{1}\right) \mu_{2}\left(r_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)-\phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right) \mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)
$$

After some straightforward calculations, using the fact that $(r, \theta) \rightarrow \phi_{n}(r) \mu_{1}(\theta)$ is Lipschitz on $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, and $r \rightarrow \phi_{n}(r) \mu_{2}(r, \theta)$ is Lipschitz (with Lipschitz constant that does not depend on $\theta$ ), it is possible to show that (5.6) is smaller or equal than

$$
C_{n} \mu_{1}\left(\theta_{1}\right)\left(r_{1}-r_{2}\right)^{2}+C_{n}\left|r_{1}-r_{2}\right|\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right|+\phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right)\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)
$$

where $C_{n}$ is a positive constant depending on $n$ which may vary from one occurrence to the other. The last term of (5.7) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right)\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad \leq \phi_{n}\left(r_{2}\right)\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{1}\right)+\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad \leq C_{n}\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right|\left|r_{1}-r_{2}\right|+\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall the elementary inequality $a b \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)$. Therefore in order to get the desired inequality (5.5), it is enough to prove that for fixed $r$, there exists a positive constant $C_{n}$ such that

$$
\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{2}\right)\right) \leq C_{n}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Let $F\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right):=\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{2}\right)\right)$. First observe that $F\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)=F\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{1}\right)$, so it is enough to consider the case $\theta_{1} \leq \theta_{2}$.

We claim that it is enough to prove inequality (5.8) for $\theta_{1}$ close to $\theta_{2}$, say $\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| \leq \frac{\pi}{4}$. Indeed assume that for a $\delta>0$, (5.8) holds for $\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| \leq \delta$. Let $M:=\sup _{\theta \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mu_{2}(r, \theta)\right|$, and set $D_{n}:=\frac{2 M}{3} \vee C_{n}$. This entails that, for $\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| \geq \delta$

$$
\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{2}\right)\right) \leq\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| 2 M \leq\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| \delta D_{n} \leq D_{n}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

and if $\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right|<\delta$, then trivially,

$$
\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{1}\right)-\mu_{2}\left(r, \theta_{2}\right)\right) \leq D_{n}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Now, it suffices to replace $C_{n}$ by $D_{n}$ in (5.8).
If $G_{k} \notin\left[\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right]$, for any $k \in \mathbb{Z}$, then $\theta \rightarrow \mu_{2}(r, \theta)$ is Lipschitz and (5.8) follows. Now let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ be such that for some $k \in \mathbb{Z}, G_{k} \in\left[\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right[$. Since the function $\theta \rightarrow \mu_{2}(r, \theta)$ is periodic, it suffices to consider:
(1) angles $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ such that $G_{1}=\frac{5 \pi}{4} \in\left[\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right]$, and $\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| \leq \frac{\pi}{4}$. This corresponds to $\left.\theta_{1} \in\right] \pi, \frac{5 \pi}{4}[$ and $\left.\theta_{2} \in\right] \frac{5 \pi}{4}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}[$. The right hand-side of (5.8) becomes $v\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(-\frac{\sin \theta_{1}}{r}-\frac{\cos \theta_{2}}{r}\right) \leq 0$, hence (5.8) is trivially satisfied.
(2) angles $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ such that $G_{0}=\frac{\pi}{4} \in\left] \theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right[$ and $\left|\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right| \leq \frac{\pi}{4}$. This corresponds to $\left.\theta_{1} \in\right] 0, \frac{\pi}{4}[$ and $\left.\theta_{2} \in\right] \frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{2}\left[\right.$. Similarly, the right hand-side of (5.8) becomes $v\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\left(\frac{\sin \theta_{1}}{r}+\frac{\cos \theta_{2}}{r}\right) \leq 0$.
The limiting cases $G_{k} \in\left[\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right], G_{k}=\theta_{2}$ and $G_{k} \in\left[\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right], G_{k}=\theta_{1}$ are treated similarly and (5.5) is proved.

In order to prove the existence and uniqueness of a strong solution, we first prove pathwise uniqueness and then the existence of a weak solution. Let $T>0, t \in[0, T], n$ be fixed and $\phi(s):=\phi_{n}(s), R_{t}:=R_{t}^{n, A^{s}}, \Theta_{t}:=\Theta_{t}^{n, A^{s}}$. Let $\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t}\right)$ and $\left(R_{t}^{\prime}, \Theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)$ be two solutions of the system (5.4). By Itô's Lemma,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left(\left(R_{t}-R_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left(\Theta_{t}-\Theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right) & \\
= & 2 \mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left[\left(R_{s}-R_{s}^{\prime}\right)\left(\phi\left(R_{s}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{s}\right)-\phi\left(R_{s}^{\prime}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{s}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right.\right. & \\
& \left.\left.+\left(\Theta_{s}-\Theta_{s}^{\prime}\right)\left(\phi\left(R_{s}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}, \Theta_{s}\right)-\phi\left(R_{s}^{\prime}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}^{\prime}, \Theta_{s}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right] d s\right) & \\
& +2 \mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left(\Theta_{s}-\Theta_{s}^{\prime}\right)\left(\phi\left(R_{s}\right)-\phi\left(R_{s}^{\prime}\right)\right) \sigma d W_{s}\right)+\mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left(\phi\left(R_{s}\right)-\phi\left(R_{s}^{\prime}\right)\right)^{2} \sigma^{2} d s\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the monotonicity property (5.5), the Lipschitz property of $\phi$ and the fact that the stochastic integral is a martingale, for a positive constant $C,(5.9)$ is bounded from above by

$$
C \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left(\left(R_{s}-R_{s}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left(\Theta_{s}-\Theta_{s}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right) d s
$$

In order to prove the martingale property, since $\phi$ is bounded, it suffices to show that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left(\Theta_{t}\right)^{2} d t\right)<\infty
$$

From (5.4) it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left(\Theta_{t}\right)^{2} & \leq 3 \theta_{0}^{2}+3 \mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{t} \phi\left(R_{s}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}, \Theta_{s}\right) d s\right)^{2}+3 \mathbb{E}\left(\sigma \int_{0}^{t} \phi\left(R_{s}\right) d W_{s}\right)^{2} \\
& \leq 3 \theta_{0}^{2}+3 t \mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left(\phi\left(R_{s}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}, \Theta_{s}\right)\right)^{2} d s\right)+3 \sigma^{2} \mathbb{E}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left(\phi\left(R_{s}\right)\right)^{2} d s\right)<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the Cauchy-Schwartz inequality and the Itô's isometry. This shows that (5.11) is satisfied. From (5.9) and (5.10), by the Grönwall's inequality, for all $t \in[0, T]$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(\left(R_{t}-R_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\left(\Theta_{t}-\Theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right)=0
$$

therefore, since the process is continuous, pathwise uniqueness holds.
We now prove the existence of a weak solution on $[0, T]$, for any $T>0$. Let $\left(B_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ be a standard Brownian motion on $\left(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right), \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}\right)$. Then the following system has Lipschitz and bounded coefficients:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}=\phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}=\sigma d B_{t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

The existence of a unique strong solution to (5.12), for $t \in[0, T]$, follows from standard results, see for example $\left[6\right.$, Chap. 5, Thm 2.9]. Since the function $\phi(r) \mu_{2}(r, \theta)$ is bounded for $(r, \theta) \in$ $[0, \infty[\times \mathbb{R}$, then Novikov's condition implies that the process

$$
Z_{t}=\exp \left\{-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{t} \frac{\left[\phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}, \Theta_{s}\right)\right]^{2}}{\sigma} d s+\int_{0}^{t} \frac{\phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}, \Theta_{s}\right)}{\sigma} d B_{s}\right\}, \quad t \in[0, T]
$$

is a martingale. Let $\mathbb{Q}_{T}$ be the probability measure on $\left(\Omega, \mathcal{F}_{T}\right)$ defined as $d \mathbb{Q}_{T}=Z_{T} d \mathbb{P}_{r, \theta}$. By Girsanov's theorem the process

$$
d B_{t}^{\prime}=d B_{t}-\int_{0}^{t} \phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{s}, \Theta_{s}\right) d s, \quad t \in[0, T]
$$

is a $\left(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right), \mathbb{Q}_{T}\right)$ Brownian motion. Under this Brownian motion, system (5.12) becomes

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d R_{t}=\phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}\right) d t \\
d \Theta_{t}=\phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{2}\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t}\right)+\sigma d B_{t}^{\prime}
\end{array}\right.
$$

so that $\left(R_{t}, \Theta_{t}\right)$ is a weak solution to (5.4) in $[0, T]$. Weak existence and strong uniqueness imply that there exists a unique strong solution to (5.4) in $[0, T]$.

It remains to prove is that $\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}<\sqrt{2} \frac{\left(R_{0}-\eta\right)}{v}$ for every $\eta>0$. The process $R_{t}$ satisfies the equation

$$
R_{\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}}=R_{0}+\int_{0}^{\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}} \phi\left(R_{t}\right) \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}\right) d t
$$

If $R_{t} \geq \eta$, then $\phi\left(R_{t}\right)=1$ and, by (5.2) and (5.3), it follows that $\mu_{1}(\theta) \leq-\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}}$ for every $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$. Therefore

$$
\eta=R_{\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}}=R_{0}+\int_{0}^{\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}} \mu_{1}\left(\Theta_{t}\right) d t \leq R_{0}-\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}} \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}
$$

so

$$
\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}} \leq \sqrt{2} \frac{\left(R_{0}-\eta\right)}{v}
$$

Since $\tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}$ is bounded and (5.4) admits a strong solution in $[0, T]$, for any $T>0$, it follows that it also admits a strong solution in $\left[0, \tau_{\eta}^{A^{*}}\right]$ and this completes the proof.

abstract:
We formulate the optimal control problem for a sailboat aiming to reach an
upwind buoy, assuming that the wind speed is constant and the wind direction
follows a Brownian motion. The yacht navigates in $\R^2$ and the target is a
ball of radius $\eta >0$ centered at the origin. We derive the equations of
motion and provide their closed-form solution. The yacht is subject to a
tacking cost $c\geq 0$. We define two control problems, one where $c=0$ and
another where $c>0$. For both cases, we establish an analytical upper bound on
the value function by constructing a strategy that enables the yacht to reach
the buoy within a finite expected number of tacks. For the case with $c = 0$,
where no tacking cost applies, we conjecture an optimal strategy which may
involve an infinite number of tacks. The controlled state equation has
non-continuous coefficients so standard results on existence and uniqueness of
a strong solution do not apply. We provide a proof using the Yamada-Watanabe
argument.
